More to commodity slump than Chinese and Greek drama Events in Greece and China are the obvious culprits behind the falls in iron ore and metals, but there's more to the slumping prices.
PT0M0S 620 349 Autoplay On Off Video feedback Video settings Australia's struggling iron ore juniors are hitting back over the brave new normal in prices that threatens to crush their businesses by running push polling in the heartland of Western Australia against BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto.
Residents are asked in random robo-polling whether BHP and Rio pay enough tax and royalties, have too much influence over governments and are putting too much supply into the market.
Fairfax Media has received numerous calls from people reporting the phone polling, which is automated, in recent weeks. Sources have told Fairfax Media it is being run by a group of junior players, under the Yilgarn Iron Producers Association (YIPA), banner. The group has five main members, with US miner Cliffs Natural Resources and Chris Ellison's Mineral Resources the most well known.
In the calls, WA residents have been asked whether BHP and Rio have too much influence over the State Government and the Commonwealth Government, and whether they pay enough money in royalties and tax. Photo: Louise Douvis
YIPA declined to comment.
Advertisement The iron ore price could be headed below $US50 a tonne again, after falling 5.4 per cent overnight Monday to $US52. Miners had been granted some reprieve, with prices hovering around $US60, since hitting a 10-year nadir of $US47 a tonne in early April. But last week the gains started to fall away.
Push polling, first developed in the United States, involves questions designed to promote policies, or to sledge opponents. It is understood at least 800 residents - the general size for a state poll - have been contacted on behalf of YIPA.
The iron ore price could be headed below $US50 a tonne again, after falling 5.4 per cent overnight Monday to $US52. Photo: Bloomberg
The polling is understood to have finished, and the results could be used for lobbying, or as part of a broader national campaign.
In the calls, WA residents have been asked whether BHP and Rio have too much influence over the State Government and the Commonwealth Government, and whether they pay enough money in royalties and tax. Respondents are given options - for example - whether BHP and Rio - pay too much, too little, or the right amount of tax. Residents are also asked about the two majors' supply strategies - whether the level of supply they are putting into the market is too great.
Details around gender, age, highest level of education obtained, who they voted for in the last State election and who they intend on voting for in the next State election are also understood to have been asked.
Fortescue's Twiggy Forrest is understood not to be a part of the push polling but has been a critic of the big miners. Photo: Geoff Jones
YIGA's other members include Radar Iron, Cazaly Resources and Mindax. Its member base exports a combined 17 million tonnes a year from the Yilgarn region, which is about 1000 kilometres south of the Pilbara iron ore district.
The Fortescue Metals Group camp, led by Andrew Forrest, have also adopted a grassroots approach, after failing in a very public campaign to get a Federal iron ore inquiry up earlier this year. The miner is trying to build support more slowly - and quietly - from the ground up this time. Its grassroots campaign, called Our Iron Ore, is still alive. Some people who were polled were under the impression Mr Forrest was involved but Fairfax Media has since learnt that YIPA has commissioned it.
Mr Forrest, and a growing contingent of the local junior sector, blame Rio and BHP for the collapse in the iron ore price - which has lost about 60 per cent of its value since January last year.
Two months ago, US miner Cliffs Natural Resources - a YIPA member - said the seaborne supply of iron ore to China is a "doomed, horrible business", and declared it can't wait to finish mining in WA. Speaking after a decision to cut jobs and close one of its three iron ore pits in Western Australia, Cliffs chief executive Lourenco Goncalves said big miners like BHP and Rio were trying to scare the iron ore market into pessimism with their expansion plans, but could no longer afford those expansions.
At current prices of about $US52 a tonne, most of the iron ore sector outside of the big four producers is underwater.
